channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sweeping New Restrictions Take Aim at Protesters Camped Out in Kiev
item.description: The Ukrainian Parliament outlawed tents in public spaces and imposed other restrictions aimed at clearing out hundreds of demonstrators from Independence Square in the capital.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A fight broke out Thursday during a budget debate in Ukraine’s Parliament. A law was also passed that sought to curb antigovernment protests.

item.title: Egypt’s Crackdown Belies Constitution as It Nears Approval
item.description: Rights advocates said a government crackdown on journalists and dissenters belied the promises of free speech in the revised constitution that received overwhelming approval this week.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Poll workers in Cairo sorted ballots on Wednesday, the last day of a referendum in which a revised constitution received overwhelming approval.

item.title: About New York: All That Remained of 100 Elephants: A Ton of Ivory, Turned Into Trinkets
item.description: New York City has the largest market for illegal ivory sales in the country. While it is against the law, the crime rarely results in prison time for poachers or sellers.
item.dc:creator: By JIM DWYER
item.media:description: Investigators found nearly a ton of ivory from elephant tusks at a jeweler’s office in New York City, transformed into beads and chess sets, bone-white animal figures and toys.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Prosecutors in Corruption Inquiry Reassigned
item.description: Turkish officials on Thursday reassigned 20 prosecutors working on a corruption inquiry that has targeted the inner circle of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Uighur Scholar Detained
item.description: A scholar known for his criticism of the discrimination against Uighurs, a predominantly Muslim ethnic group, has been detained by the police, his wife said.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: British Police Arrest 2 Women in Terror Inquiry
item.description: British police officers, acting on intelligence information, arrested two women in London on Thursday on suspicion of terrorism offenses.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Top Generals Dismissed
item.description: President Goodluck Jonathan on Thursday fired his military’s leaders after a court ruled that their appointments had been illegal.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Outspoken Uighur Scholar Detained in Beijing
item.description: Ilham Tohti, an economist, has been critical of Chinese policies in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, and said economic discrimination fueled dissatisfaction among Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking minority group.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Guzaili Nu'er, left, with her mother-in-law, Nasipuhan, tells how the police took her husband, Ilham Tohti, from their Beijing apartment.

item.title: Listening Post: A Bill Stokes Debate, and Doubt, on Iran Deal
item.description: A Senate bill that lays down the contours of an acceptable final nuclear agreement with Iran is condemned by the White House as a deal-killer.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, before an intelligence meeting on Iran in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Party Issues Rules to Curb ‘Naked’ Corruption
item.description: The Communist Party has barred the advancement of wayward cadres in its ranks.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Lei Zhengfu, a former Communist Party official in Chongqing, at his corruption trial in June 2013.

item.title: The Lede: Video From U.N. Panel Grilling Vatican Officials on Abuse of Children
item.description: At a United Nations meeting in Geneva, committee members questioned Vatican officials about sexual abuse cases by the clergy involving children.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:description: Bishop Charles J. Scicluna, left, and other Catholic Church officials in Geneva.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Say Cease-Fire Deals Prove Deceptive
item.description: Officials from the United States and Russia have urged localized cease-fires to jump-start peace talks, but some rebels have regretted making deals with the state.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrian families in October leaving Moadhamiya. That town recently accepted a cease-fire offer, but rebels say the government has not kept its promises.

item.title: Kerry Offers Assurances as Syria Talks Draw Near
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry urged “a positive vote” as the Syrian opposition weighed whether to join a peace conference scheduled for next week.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Congress Restricts Drones Program Shift
item.description: Congress is placing restrictions on the Obama administration’s plan to shift responsibility for armed drones toward the military and away from the C.I.A.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Senator John McCain supports the Obama administration’s plans to shift responsibility for drone strikes to the military.

item.title: Egypt’s Crackdown Belies Constitution as It Nears Approval
item.description: Rights advocates said a government crackdown on journalists and dissenters belied the promises of free speech in the revised constitution that received overwhelming approval this week.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A judge in Cairo counted ballots Wednesday in a referendum seen as giving electoral legitimacy to the military takeover.

item.title: European Car Sales Ended Year on High Note, Sort Of
item.description: New car registrations, a proxy for sales, fell over the year as a whole but rose 13.3 percent year-on-year in December, the fastest growth since 2009.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Let’s Cease the Insults, North Korea Says to South
item.description: A proposal by North Korea calls for an end to all the cross-border invective both sides have hurled at each other for decades.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Apatzingán Journal: Under Gang’s Rule, a Mexican City Loses Hope in the State
item.description: Apatzingán has been under the control of a gang called the Knights Templar, with little interference from state or federal authority.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shop was burned in Apatzingán, Mexico. Many thought the attack was a message from the gang the Knights Templar.

item.title: Climate Aids in Study Face Big Obstacles
item.description: The latest draft report by United Nations climate experts cites technologies that are still in their infancy, with few projects operating around the world.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: News Analysis: In South Sudan, Some Lessons of Rwanda Learned, Others Revisited
item.description: The United Nations has taken greater steps to protect civilians from the conflict, and while approval for reinforcements has come quickly, the troops and equipment have not.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Civilians seeking protection stacked their belongings outside the gate of the United Nations compound in Bentiu, South Sudan.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 3rd Arrest in Rape of Danish Tourist
item.description: The police in New Delhi arrested a third man on Thursday in connection with the gang-rape of a Danish tourist and said they were still seeking five other men.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: U.N. Panel Questions Vatican on Handling of Clergy Sexual Abuse
item.description: It was the first prolonged interrogation by an international body and a moment long awaited by abuse victims in many countries.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Silvano Tomasi, the Vatican's representative to the United Nations, left, spoke to Msgr. Charles J. Scicluna, the Vatican's former chief sex crimes prosecutor, in Geneva on Thursday.

item.title: Italian Port Chosen as Transfer Point for Syrian Chemicals
item.description: The port of Gioia Tauro, one of the busiest in Europe, was picked because of its facilities for transferring cargo ship-to-ship.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: The Lede: Al Jazeera Denies That Journalists Detained in Egypt Confessed to Terror Charges
item.description: Egypt said journalists from Al Jazeera English detained on Dec. 29 had “confessed” to being members of the Muslim Brotherhood, but their network denied the claim.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: The Lede: Free Markets, Infidelity and the President of France
item.description: Among President François Hollande’s proposed changes – while dealing with revelations of his supposed infidelity with an actress – was a pledge to cut public spending and slash the payroll taxes for business.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: François Hollande, the president of France, after voting in the April 22, 2012, election that brought him to power. Seated next to him is his partner, Valérie Trierweiler.
